concept.title: Troubleshooting
concept.shortdesc: The troubleshooting topic type provides markup for corrective action information such as troubleshooting and alarm clearing.

section.title: The troubleshooting information type
section.draft-comment: I think all the other topic types use the section title "The purpose of the xyz information type", followed by "The structure of the xyz information type"
section.p: In its simplest form, troubleshooting information follows this pattern:

ol.li: A condition or symptom. Usually the condition or symptom is an undesirable state in a system, a product, or a service that a reader wants to correct.
A cause for the condition or symptom.
A remedy for the condition or symptom.

section.p: The troubleshooting topic provides sections for describing the condition, causes, and remedies needed to restore a system, a product, or a service to normal.

For some conditions there could be more than one cause-remedy pair. The troubleshooting topic accommodates this. Typically, a cause is immediately followed by its remedy. Multiple cause-remedy pairs can provide a series of successive fall-backs for resolving a condition. An optional diagnostics section can be included to assist in determining which of the cause-remedy pairs applies to the specific situation.
Cause and remedy might occur in combinations other than pairs. It is possible to have:

ul.li: Multiple causes with the same remedy
A single cause with more than one remedy
A remedy with no known cause
A cause with no known remedy

section.p: The troubleshooting information type also can be used to document alarm clearing strategies.

section.title: The structure of the troubleshooting topic
section.p: The top-level element for troubleshooting topics is troubleshooting. The troubleshooting element contains a title, a short description or abstract, a prolog, a troublebody, and related-links.
troublebody is the main body element in a troubleshooting topic. The troublebody element contains the following elements:

dlentry.dd: This optional element is the first child of troublebody, and it describes a condition or symptom that is associated with an undesirable state in a system, a product, or a service. Do not use this element in cases where the topic title fully explains the condition.

This optional element precedes troubleSolution and provides information used to determine which cause-remedy pair applies in a given situation.
The diagnostics element contains one of the following elements:
diagnostics-general This element provides non-procedural diagnostic information, such as a flowchart diagram or a look-up table of symptoms. Results of the diagnostic may link to the specific cause-remedy section that applies to each result.
diagnostics-steps This element provides step-by-step instructions for diagnosing the problem. Step results may link to the specific cause-remedy section that applies.

One or more troubleSolution elements appears in the troublebody element. troubleSolution is a wrapper element for cause and remedy, each of which are a cause-remedy pair.Not certain, but I Think "each of which are a cause-remedy pair" can be removed? I think it's not adding anything and I'm not entirely sure exactly what "each" refers to.

section.p: The troubleSolution element contains the following elements:

dlentry.dd: This optional, repeatable, first-child ofcondition troubleSolution describes a possible cause for the condition.

dd.p: This optional, repeatable, last-child of troubleSolution describes a possible remedy for the condition.

The remedy element begins with an optional title element followed by an optional responsibleParty element followed by either a steps element, a steps-unordered element, or a steps-informal element. The content models for steps, steps-unordered, and steps-informal are borrowed from task. This allows remedy to reuse steps from tasks.

dlentry.dd: This optional first child of remedy indicates who is expected to perform the steps that are outlined in the remedy element.

Blinking lights Printer indicator lights are blinking, indicating an error of some kind. The printer indicator lights are blinking and you are unable to print.

Use the table below to determine the problem.

  • Resume light: Flashing

  • Resume light: Flashing

  • Right cartridge light: Off

  • Right cartridge light: Flashing

  • Error light: Flashes for five seconds

 An unsupported device, such as a mouse, has been connected to the front USB port. Disconnect the unsupported device.
Clearing a paper jam Turn off the printer. Remove the rear access door by pressing the handle to the right and pulling out the door. Remove any paper that is inside the printer by pulling the paper out from the back of the printer. Replace the rear access door. If the paper jam cannot be removed from the back of the printer, raise the printer cover, remove the paper jam from the front of the printer, and then lower the cover. Turn on the printer and print the document again. Restarting the printer Press the Power button to turn off the printer, and then press the Power button to restart the printer. Proceed to step 2 if the lights continue to flash. Press the Power button to turn off the printer. Disconnect the printer power cord from the electrical outlet. Reconnect the printer power cord to the electrical outlet. Press the Power button to turn on the printer. Cleaning ink cartridge Raise the printer cover, remove the print cartridge on the right, and then lower the cover. Follow one of these steps. If the light is flashing: Open the printer cover, replace the print cartridge that you removed, and then remove the other print cartridge. Proceed to step 3. If the light is off: There is a problem with the print cartridge that you removed. Proceed to step 3. Manually clean the print cartridge. After cleaning the print cartridge, reinsert it into the printer. If the light continues to flash, replace the print cartridge. Replacing ink cartridge Turn on the printer. Make sure to load the printer with plain, white paper. Gently grasp the handles on either side of the printer and raise the ink cartridge access door until it locks in place. The carriage moves to the center of the printer. Wait until the carriage is idle and silent before you proceed. Lift the lid on the ink cartridge slot, then gently push the lid back until it stops. Pull up on the ink cartridge to remove it from the slot. Remove one of the new ink cartridges from its package, being careful to touch only the black plastic on the cartridge. Remove the plastic tape from the ink cartridge. Do not touch the copper-colored contacts or the ink nozzles. Do not replace the protective tape on the contacts. Handling these parts can result in clogs, ink failure, and bad electrical connections. Hold the ink cartridge by its sides with the nozzles toward the printer, then slide the ink cartridge forward into the slot. Close the lid on the ink cartridge slot to secure the ink cartridge in place. Repeat the previous steps to install the other ink cartridge if necessary. Close the ink cartridge access door. The printer automatically prints an alignment page. Wait for the alignment page to fully eject from the printer. Lift the scanner lid. Place the alignment page with the print side down on the scanner glass according to the engraved guides around the glass. Close the scanner lid and touch OK. The printer aligns the ink cartridges.
